article: The Christmas gift when I was seven years old has been a pleasant memory. _ other gifts, it came without wrap . On September 11ththat year, Mum gave _ to Richard. After she brought him home from _ ,she put him in my lap, saying, "I _ you a gift, and here it is." What a/an _ ! I _ seven amonth earlier and none of my friends had such a baby doll of their own. I played with it day and night and told it over and over how much I loved it! One morning, however, I found its bed empty. My doll was _ ! I cried for it. Mum wept and told me that the _ little thing had been sent to a hospital because of a fever. For several days, I heard mum andDad whispering such _ as "hopeless", "pitiful", and "dying", which sounded _ . Christmas was coming. "Don't _ any presents this year," Dad said, pointing at the _ I hung in the living room. " _ your baby brother lives, that'll be Christmas enough." As he spoke, his eyes filled with tears. I'd _ seen him cry before. The phone rang early on Christmas morning. Dad jumped out of bed to _ it. From my bedroom I heard him say, "What? He's all right?" He hung up and shouted upstairs. "The hospital said we can bring Richard home!" "Thank God!" I heard Mum cry. From the upstairs window, I watched my parents rush out to the car. I had never seen them so _ . And I was also full of joy. What a wonderful day! My baby doll would be home. I ran _ . My socks still hung there _ , but I knew they were filled with _ !
